messages.content:
You are a professional academic reference prediction expert. Your task is to predict the most likely references for a given academic paper based on its title, abstract, and retrieved relevant papers.

RETRIEVER INTERFACE:
- Input: paper title + abstract
- Output: {top_r} retrieved papers with title and abstract
- Format: List of dictionaries with 'title' and 'abstract' fields

REQUIREMENTS:
1. Analyze the paper's title and abstract to understand its research area and focus
2. Consider the retrieved papers as potential references (when available)
3. Generate a list of predicted reference titles that would be most relevant and likely to be cited
4. Provide reasoning for each prediction to prevent hallucination
5. Output format: JSON object with "titles" array and "reasoning" string
6. Generate exactly 49 most relevant reference titles (this should be at least 40 to cover all evaluation metrics)
7. Ensure titles are realistic and appropriate for the research area
8. Consider citation patterns in the field
9. CRITICAL: Each title must be unique - never repeat the same title multiple times

EXAMPLE:
Input:
Title: "Question Type Classification Methods Comparison"
Abstract: "The paper presents a comparative study of state-of-the-art approaches for question classification task: Logistic Regression, Convolutional Neural Networks (CNN), Long Short-Term Memory Network (LSTM) and Quasi-Recurrent Neural Networks (QRNN). All models use pre-trained GLoVe word embeddings and trained on human-labeled data. The best accuracy is achieved using CNN model with five convolutional layers and various kernel sizes stacked in parallel, followed by one fully connected layer. The model reached 90.7% accuracy on TREC 10 test set."

Retrieved papers ({top_r}):
1. Title: Convolutional Neural Networks for Sentence Classification
   Abstract: We report on a series of experiments with convolutional neural networks trained on top of pre-trained word vectors for sentence-level classification tasks.

2. Title: Glove: Global vectors for word representation
   Abstract: We present a new global log-bilinear regression model that combines the advantages of the two major model families in the literature.

Output:
{
  "titles": [
    "Convolutional Neural Networks for Sentence Classification",
    "Glove: Global vectors for word representation",
    "Quasi-Recurrent Neural Networks",
    "A Comparative Study of Neural Network Models for Sentence Classification",
    "Deep lstm based feature mapping for query classification"
  ],
  "reasoning": "Based on the paper's focus on question classification using neural networks, I predict these references because: 1) CNN paper is directly relevant to the convolutional approach used; 2) GloVe embeddings are mentioned as pre-trained features; 3) QRNN is one of the compared methods; 4) Comparative study papers are common in this field; 5) LSTM-based query classification is closely related to question classification. Additional references cover related neural network architectures, NLP applications, deep learning methodologies, optimization techniques, and advanced neural network methods that would be relevant for this research area."
}

Return JSON object only.

Paper Title: Linear-time Temporal Logic with Team Semantics: Expressivity and Complexity

Paper Abstract: Abstract We study the expressivity and complexity of model checking of linear temporal logic with team semantics (TeamLTL). TeamLTL, despite being a purely modal logic, is capable of defining hyperproperties, i.e., properties which relate multiple execution traces. TeamLTL has been introduced quite recently and only few results are known regarding its expressivity and its model checking problem. We relate the expressivity of TeamLTLTeamLTL\mathrm{TeamLTL} to logics for hyperproperties obtained by extending LTL with trace and propositional quantifiers (HyperLTLHyperLTL\mathrm{HyperLTL} and HyperQPTLHyperQPTL\mathrm{HyperQPTL}). By doing so, we obtain a number of model checking results for TeamLTLTeamLTL\mathrm{TeamLTL} and identify its undecidability frontier. In particular, we show decidability of model checking of the so-called left-flat fragment of any downward closed TeamLTLTeamLTL\mathrm{TeamLTL}-extension. Moreover, we establish that the model checking problem of TeamLTLTeamLTL\mathrm{TeamLTL} with Boolean disjunction and inclusion atoms is undecidable.

{retrieved_text}

Generate exactly 49 most likely reference titles for this paper. Focus on papers that are directly related to the research topic, provide foundational background, present similar methodologies, or address related problems.

CRITICAL: Each title must appear exactly once. Do not repeat any title.

IMPORTANT: You must respond with ONLY valid JSON in this exact format:
{
    "titles": [
        "Reference Title 1",
        "Reference Title 2",
        "Reference Title 3",
        "Reference Title 4",
        "Reference Title 49"
    ],
    "reasoning": "Explain why you chose these specific references based on the paper's title, abstract, and retrieved papers. This helps prevent hallucination and ensures relevance."
}

Do not include any text before or after the JSON. Do not include authors, venues, or years - only the paper titles. The reasoning field is required to explain your prediction logic.

{
    "titles": [
        "Hyperpctl: A temporal logic for probabilistic hyperproperties",
        "Runtime verification of k-safety hyperproperties in hyperltl",
        "A really temporal logic",
        "A temporal logic for asynchronous hyperproperties",
        "Unifying hyper and epistemic temporal logics",
        "NuSMV: A new symbolic model verifier",
        "Temporal logics for hyperproperties",
        "Hyperproperties",
        "The hierarchy of hyperlogics",
        "Runtime enforcement of hyperproperties",
        "Temporal property verification as a program analysis task",
        "A logical approach to context-specific independence",
        "Probabilistic team semantics",
        "Canonical representations of k-safety hyperproperties",
        "Deciding hyperproperties",
        "Realizing ømega-regular hyperproperties",
        "Synthesis from hyperproperties",
        "Monitoring hyperproperties",
        "Algorithms for model checking HyperLTL and HyperCTL∗",
        "Inclusion Logic and Fixed Point Logic",
        "Hyperldlf: a logic for checking properties of finite traces process logs",
        "Automata and fixpoints for asynchronous hyperproperties",
        "A finite axiomatization of conditional independence and inclusion dependencies",
        "Descriptive complexity of real computation and probabilistic independence logic",
        "Complexity of propositional logics in team semantic",
        "Model checking and validity in propositional and modal inclusion logics",
        "The expressive power of modal dependence logic",
        "On verifying timed hyperproperties",
        "The model checker SPIN",
        "A Logic for Arguing About Probabilities in Measure Teams",
        "Coherence and computational complexity of quantifier-free dependence logic formulas",
        "A van benthem theorem for modal team semantics",
        "A team based variant of CTL",
        "Team Semantics for the Specification and Verification of Hyperproperties",
        "A double team semantics for generalized quantifiers",
        "On the complexity of linear temporal logic with team semantics",
        "The keys to decidable hyperltl satisfiability: Small models or very simple formulas",
        "Proving noninterference and functional correctness using traces",
        "Temporal logic and fair discrete systems",
        "The Temporal Logic of Programs",
        "A Temporal Logic Approach to Information-Flow Control",
        "CSP and determinism in security modelling",
        "Characterising modal definability of team-based logics via the universal modality",
        "Lossy counter machines decidability cheat sheet",
        "The complexity of propositional linear temporal logics",
        "Dependence Logic",
        "Modal dependence logic",
        "Propositional logics of dependence",
        "Propositional team logics"
    ],
    "reasoning": "Selected these 49 references because they represent foundational work and recent advances in Linear-time Temporal Logic with Team Semantics: Expressivity and Complexity, providing essential background knowledge and methodological foundations relevant to this research."
}
